importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the satellite launch and announcement marks a significant milestone in Pakistan's space program and national technological advancement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The launch of H1 occurs within a broader timeline of Pakistan's space program activity, with three satellites launched this year, suggesting a strategic push toward space capability development.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space program.
The satellite was successfully launched from China's Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
Hyperspectral satellites detect subtle chemical or material changes on the ground, useful for agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster response.
The satellite supports national objectives in precision agriculture, urban planning, and climate resilience.
The technology will help Pakistan assess geohazard risks and support development initiatives like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
The launch reflects Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration and technological cooperation.
Two other satellites, EO-1 and KS-1, are already fully operational in orbit.
It may take about two months to calibrate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational.

SUPARCO, Pakistan’s national space agency, announced the success of the mission, with Chairman Muhammad Yousuf Khan emphasizing its potential to revolutionize agriculture and natural resource management.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development initiative linking China’s Xinjiang and Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite’s capability to assess geohazard risks directly supports CPEC’s infrastructure development by improving risk assessment and planning.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their operational status indicates a growing momentum in Pakistan’s space programme, with H1 as a key addition to this expanding portfolio.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This technology enables Pakistan to monitor crop quality, water resources, and disaster damage more precisely than traditional satellites.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite enables early detection of environmental damage and geohazards, improving response times and preparedness.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A long-term strategy for adapting to environmental change
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The data from H1 will help Pakistan build more resilient systems against climate-related challenges.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a major step in its space programme. The satellite, developed by the national space agency SUPARCO, is designed to detect subtle material changes on Earth’s surface, supporting applications in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management. The mission enhances Pakistan’s capacity for geohazard assessment and supports development projects like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While the satellite will require approximately two months of calibration before full operation, it is part of a broader effort by Pakistan to expand its space capabilities, including the already-operational EO-1 and KS-1 satellites. The launch underscores Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration and technological cooperation.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
